Introduction

The Health and Safety (display screen equipment) Regulations place a statutory duty on Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (hereafter referred to as the Trust) to manage the risks of working with display screen equipment (DSE). This document outlines the Trust's process and service Manager responsibilities to minimise risks to DSE users via the following:
Analyse workstations to assess and reduce risks
Ensure workstations meet specified minimum requirements
Plan work activities to include breaks or changes of activity
Provide eye and eyesight tests on request, and special spectacles if needed
provide information and training (Managers DSE guidance is included in appendix 2)
Record completed/reviewed DSE Assessment(s) and eye test dates on a DSE Schedule (Appendix 5) to aid with management of DSE annual review of DSE workstation assessments.
The Health & Safety Display Screen Equipment Regulations apply to protect users, whether they are employed to work:
(a) At their own employer's workstation;
(b) At a workstation at home; or
(c) At another employer's workstation

The main risks that may arise in work with DSE are musculoskeletal disorders such as back pain or upper limb disorders (sometimes known as repetitive strain injury or RSI), visual fatigue, and mental stress. While the risks to individual users are often low, they can still be significant if good practice is not followed.
Scope
The purpose of this policy is to relate information regarding Trust's intention to ensure that any health and safety hazards which may arise from the use of DSE equipment are reduced to a minimum by:
Ensuring staff are aware of their duties and risks.
Providing support initially via assessment.
Ensuring work stations meet requirements.
Clarifying the procedure related to eye tests and funding for optician approved corrective lenses for use with workplace DSE.
Implementing monitoring processes to ensure compliance.
All reasonable steps will be taken by the Trust to secure the health and safety of employees who work with DSE
This document covers all workers ‘users' who work with display screen equipment inclusive of the environment and the tasks in which the equipment is utilised.
NHS Constitution

The Trust is committed to designing and implementing services, policies and measures that meet the diverse needs of its population and workforce, ensuring that no individual or group is disadvantaged.
This Policy supports the NHS Constitution as follows:

The Trust aspires to the highest standards of excellence and professionalism in the provision of high-quality care that is safe, effective and focused on patient experience; in the planning and delivery of the clinical and other services it provides; in the people it employs and the education, training and development they receive; in the leadership and management of its organisations; and through its commitment to innovation and to the promotion and conduct of research to improve the current and future health and care of the population.
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex University Hospitals Group
Display Screen Equipment is any alphanumeric or graphic display screen regardless of the display process involved.

An employee who habitually uses display screen equipment as a significant part of their normal work. A person should also be classed as a user if most of, or all of the following apply; Task cannot be done effectively or at all without DSE The worker has no discretion over whether to use DSE The job requires significant training or particular skills The worker uses DSE for periods of an hour or more at a time, more or less on a daily basis The task depends on fast transfer of information between worker and screen

A workstation that is not assigned to an individual but is a shared resource within a team and will be used by a number of different people at different times. (Hot Desking - Using a number of workstations over the working day).

An assembly comprising:- display screen equipment, accessories to the display screen equipment, disk drive, telephone, modem, printer, document holder, work chair, work desk, work surface and immediate work environment around the display screen.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Health and Safety Management Group to ensure the arrangements within this policy are implemented. Receive and review reports in relation to working with display screen equipment associated safety issues and action/escalate accordingly to relevant site governance forum where necessary.
The Chief Executive has overall duty is to ensure the Trust complies with its statutory obligations in relation to The Health & Safety (Display Screen Equipment) Regulations
To delegate responsibility for monitoring compliance to Directors and Senior Managers
To ensure that reasonable resources are made available to provide equipment to minimise the risks to DSE users
5.2.1 The Directors, Associate Directors, Care Group / Directorate Managers, Heads of Departments duties are:
To ensure that managers and staff throughout their management area comply with this procedure
5.2.2 Managers' duties are:
To implement this policy within their areas of responsibility
To ensure where staff are identified as “users” that they are made aware of this procedure and the requirement to complete a workstation assessment
To ensure “users” complete a workstation assessment
To assist the DSE user with completing the workstation assessment if required (Refer to appendix 1 & 2.1 - 2.4)
To advise “users” of their entitlement to eye and eyesight testing (Refer to section 7 / Appendices 3&4)
To enable DSE user's sight tests to be reviewed at regular intervals
To advise “users” of their entitlement of a contribution towards the cost of glasses if they are required for DSE use
To ensure that staff are aware that if they do not follow the correct referral procedures they will not be reimbursed
To ensure retention of records of completed assessment forms as evidence of compliance.

To ensure the process within the Occupational Health DSE SOP is followed to support provision of eye sight tests and where identified (by and optician for workplace DSE usage) assist provision of special corrective appliances (Glasses)
To liaise with the DSE user to ensure that any requested items are appropriate.
To refer all requests for the purchase of DSE hardware/software to the IT Department
To copy the completed assessment (checklist ,findings and action plan) to Occupational Health where health issues have been identified

In rare cases it may be deemed necessary to employ the services of an ergonomic specialist (to ensure optimum equipment, environment and practices are in place to fit a service operative's workplace tasks). This should be in line with the agreed process outlined within the Occupational Health DSE SOP.

With the advent of increased ‘working from home ensure HSE Guidance and learning from the assessments is additionally applied to protect operatives. In addition to general DSE provision Managers should also consider, lone working without supervision and stress management arrangements. Guidance on this can be sourced on the HSE website: https://www.hse.gov.uk/toolbox/workers/home.htm
5.2.3 Each Ward/Department/Office Manager for their operational team must evidence:-
DSE Users are identified in the team and this is documented.
A DSE user list records when DSE Users in the department last completed a DSE Workstation Assessment. (Appendix 5)
Workstation Assessments are completed by all DSE users.
New staff must complete a DSE Assessment checklist (Appendices 2.1- 2.4) as part of their Local Induction.

Workstation assessments are reviewed whenever there is a significant change to either workstation / environment of the individual DSE user. If the aforementioned has not occurred within period of no longer than 3 years).
Issues of comfort identified through Workstation Assessments are acted upon.
Equipment necessary for safety is provided following Workstation Assessment.
Specialist support is sought from Occupational Health where an individual has a health condition or injury that must be managed at work or following an absence.

Specialist support or recommendation is sought from the Manual Handling Team where specialist equipment may be necessary to manage any conditions which originally attributed to a manual handling injury a work.
Ensure DSE Users are made aware of their entitlement to an eye and eyesight test.

Ensure Trust ‘DSE Users' are made aware of Trust arrangements for financial assistance towards costs incurred for corrective lenses which are utilised to aid the DSE user undertake their DSE tasks while at work.
Good practice with DSE use is promoted.
Where present ensure, Moving & Handling Link Co-ordinators have completed DSE user assessment training.

With the advent of increased ‘working from home ensure HSE DSE guidance and learning from the assessments is additionally applied to protect operatives. In addition to general DSE provision, Managers should consider, lone working without supervision and stress management arrangements. Guidance on this can be sourced on the HSE website: https://www.hse.gov.uk/toolbox/workers/home.htm
5.2.4 Procurement / Purchasing

Ordering and supply of work desks, chairs and other DSE related items via approved suppliers utilising agreed budget resourcing codes. When required they will seek specialist advice from the Occupational Health & wellbeing Department.
5.2.5 Occupational Health and Wellbeing Service is responsible for providing specialist advice if required for Staff members with DSE related health problems.

Members of staff who develop any health problem which they think may be related to working with DSE, must report this to their Manager. The Manager must then refer the individual to the Occupational Health Department.
Occupational Health will support the DSE process as outlined within the ‘Occupational Health DSE Standard Operating Procedure.
The Occupational Health Service also offers specialist advice and support to Managers and Individuals when an employee is:
Experiencing symptoms of a musculoskeletal disorder or have an existing health condition that needs to be managed at work.
Absent from work due to a musculoskeletal disorder or injury.
Returning to work following an absence due to a musculoskeletal injury.
5.2.6 Manual Handling ‘Advisory' Team offer specialist advice and support by telephone; email or face to face when:-
An employee returns to work following an absence due to a musculoskeletal disorder or injury.
A specialist equipment assessment has been advised by Occupational Health. Occupational Health will advise Managers to contact the Manual Handling Advisory Team direct.
Managers and individuals need advice on appropriate specialist equipment to prevent a musculoskeletal disorder or injury.
5.2.7 ‘Where present' Manual Handling Link Co-Ordinators can support Managers by:
Maintaining an up to date list of DSE Users within the Department that documents when DSE Users last completed a DSE workstation assessment.
Promoting and sharing good practice in DSE use within the team.
Providing individuals and teams the opportunity to discuss issues at Team Meetings.
Ensuring colleagues have access to the Workstation Assessment Checklist and good practice guidance.
Offering suggestions, following Workstation Assessment, where an issue of comfort has been identified.
5.2.8 Health and Safety Department duties:
To provide advice to managers and DSE users in matters relating to DSE workstations and postural safety (The latter via the Moving and Handling advisors).
To review the effectiveness of this procedure and amending the procedure as necessary
5.2.9 Information Technology (IT) Department duties:
Scrutinise all requests for DSE software or hardware purchases.
Provide equipment which complies with the schedule of minimum requirements for workstations of the Health and Safety (Display Screen Equipment) Regulations.
5.2.10 All DSE Users must:
Follow best practice guidelines when working with DSE.
Complete their own DSE Workstation Self- Assessment / Checklist and review that Assessment if there is a significant change to their workstation or a change to their health.
Ensure the DSE Workstation Assessment / Checklist is passed to their Manager.
Co-operate with their Manager to identify suitable solutions to issues of comfort identified.
Attend appointments made for eye and eyesight testing.
Attend appointments made with Occupational Health.
To discuss any MSD symptoms with their Manager at the earliest opportunity.
Report to management any faults relating to DSE equipment, furniture or working environment.
To report to management any discomfort associated with use of DSE.
Ensure safekeeping of glasses (corrective appliances). It is an offence to interfere with, or misuse, anything provided in the interest of health and safety.

Take appropriate frequent breaks away from the DSE. This is to break up long periods of sitting in one position or lengthy periods of repetitive data inputting; varying movement will prevent physical and visual fatigue.

Apply / adapt learning from DSE Assessment to home working. Information on this can be conveniently sourced on the HSE website, in addition to DSE arrangements discuss with your manager lone working and stress management arrangements for working from home to ensure ‘so far as reasonably practicable' safe working arrangements are in place at home. https://www.hse.gov.uk/toolbox/workers/home.htm
Adjust furniture or equipment so as to reduce unnecessary discomfort, this can be avoided by adopting the following simple precautions

Make sure that all furniture and equipment is functioning correctly. Adjust furniture and equipment for comfort when working. Take the opportunity to vary activities, breaking up long periods of DSE work.
Adjust furniture or equipment so as to reduce unnecessary discomfort, this can be avoided by adopting the following simple precautions
5.2.11 All Employees have a responsibility to:
Take action to address hazards in their working areas.
Ensure they are familiar with and follow good practice guidelines when working with DSE.
To report any incidents or accidents by completing an electronic Incident Reporting Form.
To discuss any MSD symptoms with their Manager at the earliest opportunity.
Process
The key risks for DSE users are:
Musculoskeletal Disorders (MSDs).
Eye and eyesight effects.
Fatigue and stress.

6.1.1 The known health problems associated with DSE work can be prevented in the majority of cases by good ergonomic design of the equipment, workplace and job; and by worker training and consultation. Risk Assessment training is available through the Trust learning and development portal.

6.1.2 There is no research evidence that DSE can cause disease or permanent damage to the eyes. However, long spells of DSE work can lead to tired eyes and discomfort; and the additional demanding tasks for the eyes by using DSE may make manifest a sight problem that the user had been previously unaware of. Eye tests are supported to ensure users can comfortably see the screen and work effectively without visual fatigue.
DSE users

6.2.1 Where it is clear that use of DSE is more or less continuous on most days, the individuals concerned should be regarded as users or operators. This will include the majority of those whose job mainly involves, for example DSE based data input or sales and order processing. Where use is less continuous or frequent, other factors connected with the job must be assessed. It will generally be appropriate to classify the person concerned as a user or operator if they:
Normally use DSE for continuous or near-continuous spells of an hour or more at a time; and
Use DSE in this way more or less daily; and

Have to transfer information quickly to or from the DSE; and also need to apply high levels of attention and concentration; or are highly dependent on DSE or have little choice about using it; or need special training or skills to use the DSE.

6.2.2 Part-time workers should be assessed using the same criteria. For example if an employee works only two days a week but spends most of that time on DSE work, that person should definitely be considered a user.
All DSE Users in the Trust:

Must complete a DSE Workstation assessment checklist (Refer to Appendices 1 & 2.1 – 2.4) as part of their local induction and after any significant change to the individual, equipment or environment. If the aforementioned does not occur the assessment should be reviewed three yearly basis.
Have entitlement to eye and eyesight testing.
Should be aware of and apply best practice when working with DSE (Refer to Appendix 1).
DSE workstation assessment checklist (Refer to appendices 2.1-2.4)
The DSE regulations require the Trust to carry out a suitable and sufficient analysis of all workstations. Managers have the responsibility to ensure these assessments are undertaken.
6.4.1 DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist
Each DSE User must:
Complete an assessment checklist (appendix 2.1-2.4). This should occur at the workstation during the first week (ideally on the first day of starting work with the Trust).
Complete a workstation assessment if they are a DSE user and work from home, whether or not the workstation is supplied by in whole or in part by the Trust
Complete a new assessment where there are any changes to their work location, technology or medical condition.
If a workstation is shared each DSE user must complete a workstation assessment to ensure that they are aware of how the workstation should be set up.
The completed assessment checklist should be given to their Line Manager for action and review period noted within the DSE Assessment review schedule
Appendix 5 (N.B. DSE Assessment must be retained for a period of 3 years post associated individual's termination of employment).

6.4.2 Proactive usage guidance for general and hand held / new generation DSE equipment. With the introduction of new generation electronic display equipment (and usage of conventional DSE equipment) the following guidance can be utilised to proactively advert common issues associated with usage. In addition refer to DSE Checklist (Appendix 2.1-2.4)
Adopt a good posture by:
Sitting tall, sliding your shoulder blades back and drawing in the core.
Making sure your back is supported as you sit
Trying not to slouch / Not sitting forward and crouching over the tablet
Placing a cushion on your lap to act as a platform.
To avoid the onset of eyestrain, when reading the screen:
Avoid glare. If glare occurs, adjust your screen in order to reduce reflections by moving to another position
Position the screen directly in front of you, and wherever possible, at a more natural focus distance (i.e. at leastinches from the face). Using a tablet stand may be more comfortable.
Adjust screen brightness to suit surrounding light levels

Adopt suggested 20-20-20 rule. (Every  minutes spent looking at a screen; a person should look at something  feet away for  seconds). This offers the eyes some of the exercise they need to stay functioning comfortably.
Regularly clean your screen.
Make a conscious effort attempt to blink at more regular intervals.
Take short, frequent breaks from the equipment:
Take a short break from using the equipment every 20-30 minutes
During these breaks stretch the muscles in the shoulders and chest and move around the area where you are working.
6.4.3 All new employees must be issued with a DSE Workstation Assessment for completion as part of their local Induction and this should be documented in the Departmental Induction Checklist.

6.4.4 All existing employees must review their DSE assessment on a three yearly basis (or when there is significant change to equipment, workstation or working environment) and this should be recorded on the departmental DSE user list. A flow chart summary of the process for undertaking and review of the DSE Assessment and arrangements of physical action arrangements are contained within the quick reference DSE summary process flow chart at the beginning of this policy.

6.4.5 The assessment or relevant parts of it should be reviewed in the light of changes to the DSE worker population, or changes in individual capability, or where there has been some significant change to the workstation such as: A DSE Workstation Assessment must be reviewed when:
Major change to any of the equipment (screen, keyboard, etc.)
Significant change to workstation or location of work.
An individual experiences MSD symptoms or is diagnosed with an MSD condition.
An individual has any other health condition that may affect their safety or comfort when working with DSE.
Major change in workstation furniture.
Substantial increase in the amount of time required to be spent using DSE.
Substantial change in other task requirements (for example greater speed or accuracy).
Workstation is relocated (even if all equipment and furniture stays the same).
Major features of the work environment, such as the lighting, are significantly modified.

6.4.6 DSE Workstation Assessments must be reviewed by Managers. Managers are responsible for ensuring that issues of comfort or safety identified by the Workstation Assessment are addressed including the purchase of any recommended equipment that will help the user.

6.4.7 Every service/department must have an up-to-date list of DSE users; Managers are responsible for ensuring the list is available and up-to-date. The DSE user list must indicate when each DSE user last completed their DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist (Ref 5 for an example template). Managers have a duty to retain a record of the assessments and keep the records for three years beyond employment termination.

6.4.8 Department Manual Handling Link Co-ordinators can support Managers by offering recommendations and advice on best working practice with DSE. Managers retain overall responsibility for ensuring issues of comfort and safety, identified by the DSE Workstation Assessment and are addressed.
6.4.9 The Manual Handling Team, (Manual Handling link co-ordinators – where present) can offer recommendations to attain optimum posture (and associated equipment) for undertaking work with DSE.
6.4.10 Occupational Health can offer Managers and individuals' advice on health conditions and how to manage them in the workplace.

6.4.11 Shared workstations: Where one workstation is used by more than one worker, whether simultaneously or in shifts, it must be analysed and assessed in relation to all those covered by the DSE Regulations. For example if a very tall and a very short worker are sharing a workstation, the assessor should check the chair has a wide enough range of adjustment to accommodate both of them, and that a footrest is available when required.
Off- site working / home working

If a DSE user is working at a location away from their main base, the DSE Regulations and this policy still apply. DSE users working off site regularly and/or for significant periods of time must show that they are managing the risks of DSE Working by completing a DSE Workstation Assessment. Managers must ensure that a DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist is completed by off-site DSE users and that individuals are aware of best practice for safety and comfort at a workstation as for anyone else on their team.

Use of laptops - If a DSE user is working with a laptop, the DSE Regulations and this policy still apply. Utilise the learning from the DSE Assessment and guidance within appendix 1 to achieve set up whereby detrimental posture is avoided i.e. utilise laptop docking station, separate keyboard and separate mouse. Utilise an office environment chair which offers optimal back support. Additionally refer to the Occupational Health DSE Standard Operating procedure for provision of specialised DSE user equipment if required.

N.B. It is important to remember that with the advent of greater requirement for working from home, following the 2020 SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, that learning from the DSE assessment must be additionally applied to home setting to prevent so far as reasonably practicable a user from developing DSE related injuries. Therefore supply of office chair and/or other equipment (via new purchase or conveyance of DSE  equipment  the home  setting  with  Managers  consent)  may  be  required  to proactively maintain a optimal/safe working condition for a DSE user. (For example office chair usage within the home to ensure the user achieves correct support and posture while in a seated position as per DSE Assessment.
Procurement of equipment

Procurement of equipment should be via established suppliers and preferably through procurement authorised supply chains. Please refer to the Occupational Health DSE Standard Operating procedure and follow Trust agreed procurement processes.
Eye sight tests and assistance with corrective appliance for use
with workplace DSE
Provision of sight tests and corrective appliances

All DSE Users are entitled to request under the DSE Regulations an ‘eyesight test', which the Department should meet through their local departmental budget. If the test shows that the DSE User requires corrective appliances for DSE work, the Trust can assist with provision off corrective lenses (to a maximum amount) with basic frames. The cost of a basic set of glasses will generally be a one off payment to the employee.
7.1.1  Eye and eyesight tests

Employees covered by the Regulations i.e. defined as “users”, can request the Trust to provide an eye and eyesight test. The Trust allocate a set financial assistance sum for this test. The current allocated monetary sum can be obtained via the Occupational Health DSE Standard Operating Procedure.
The employee should arrange this in line with the process outlined within the Occupational Health DSE Standard Operating Procedure.

There exists additional entitlement to eye sight tests at regular intervals; the optician undertaking the initial eye sight test can recommend arrangement for repeat testing. (Managers should be guided by the clinical judgement of the optician on the frequency of the repeat testing. The frequency of the repeat testing will vary between individuals according to factors such as age).

The Trust upon request will ensure that the employee is provided with an appropriate eye and eyesight test, (in most cases conducted out by an external competent person (external optician) which the Trust will fund for up to a maximum amount including VAT (Refer to the Occupational Health DSE Standard Operating Procedure).
If a referral to an optician is recommended by the Occupational Health Advisor, the employee will be given:
A letter so that the line manager is aware of the referral being made, (Appendix 3).
A letter to take to the optician identifying the requirements of the test and that it is in relation to the DSE Regulations (Appendix 4).

An expenses claim must be completed and submitted. This must be approved by your line manager to claim back the expense of the eye sight test and the corrective lenses if required specifically for DSE use. Where budget allocation exists this can be logged via the expenses system or a record form can be utilised (Appendix 4)
Corrective appliance (glasses)

If the optician identifies a need for special corrective appliances specifically for DSE use, and where normal corrective appliances cannot be used, the Trust will contribute towards the cost of basic appliances up to a maximum amount including VAT)
Follow the process outlined within the Occupational Health DSE Standard Operating procedure to access Trust support and assistance with this aspect of safe working provision.
If the employee wishes to obtain additional requirements from the basic frames and lenses then they should meet this at their own cost.
Users are entitled to further tests at regular intervals after their first test and in between if they are having visual difficulties that may be considered to be aggravated by their DSE work.
Training requirements

8.1.1  Training  is  provided  to  the  user  relating  to  DSE  workstations,  the  working environment and the software used within the Trust via induction Health and safety awareness e – learning, regular health and safety update via the H&S Team and the guidance within the policy.

Where bespoke software packages are used then specific, targeted training must be provided to the users. This means that the training should be purchased along with the software package. Provision must be made for any further training to be accessed.

Appendix 1: User guidance- assessing and usage of display screen equipment
Seating
The work chair must be the first item of equipment that is adjusted when setting up a safe workstation. The following must be adhered to:

The chair back must be adjustable for both height and tilt. There may be a very small minority of users that suffer back problems and may require this requirement to be overlooked. If the User is such a person then specialist advice must be sought from Occupational Health / Moving and Handling section of the Health and Safety Team.

The chair back should be adjusted to provide good lumbar support for the user therefore it must adjust up and down to allow the curved raised area to fit comfortably into the natural curve of the users back.

The seat pan of the chair should be height adjustable and operable while seated. It should be adjusted to allow the users forearms to be approximately horizontal in relation to the desk height and hip and knee angle to be approximately 90 degrees. If this requires the user's legs to be off the floor or a greater angle than 90 degrees at the knee, then a foot rest will be required.
It should be of adequate design to prevent pressure on the underside of the user's thighs and knees (gently sloping at the front of the chair).
It should have a five point, star shaped base with castors to allow the user mobility within their work area while still seated.
There must be sufficient space between the chair and the workstation to allow postural change both laterally and vertically.
N.B. Purchase of seating should be progressed via service manager and financed through localised budgets.
Display Screen

Once the user's seating and their desk height has been adjusted to fit them consideration should be given to whether the height of the display screen is correct. As a broad guide the user's eye line, when the head and neck position are neutral, should be approximately 5 cm (2”) from the top of the screen (The screen should both swivel and tilt with ease).
Display screen characters should be well-defined and clearly formed. They should be of adequate size and spacing between characters and lines should be appropriate.
The screen should show no flickering or other forms of instability.
The  brightness and  contrast between  characters in  the  background  should be  easily adjustable by the user.
It should be possible to use a separate base for the screen or an adjustable table. This should allow the screen to be positioned for the comfort of the user.

It should be free from reflective glare; this may be due to poor positioning. If there is glare on the screen check its position in relation to lighting and windows. Glare can also be caused by shiny objects within the area for example reflective furniture and metal objects.
Keyboard

The arrangement of the keyboard and the characteristics of the keys should be easy to use. It should be able to tilt and be separate from the screen, allowing the user to find the most comfortable working position to avoid fatigue in the upper body. The symbols on the keys should be adequately contrasted and legible. The keyboard should have a matt surface to avoid reflective glare. There should be enough space in front of the keyboard to allow the user to sufficiently support their arms and hands. As a guideline a minimum of 5 cm (2”) should be allowed.
Mouse / Trackball

The mouse / trackball are designed to complete many tasks and are available in a variety of shapes and sizes. It is important that the correct item is supplied for the needs of the user and the tasks they wish to complete. In the majority of cases this would be the basic shaped mouse. Best practice shows that the user should not leave their hand on the device when it is not in use. The user's arm should be relaxed and wrist as straight as possible.
N.B. Purchase of IT hardware should be progressed via service manager. In most cases requests can be logged onto the IT portal and authorised / financed via localised service budgets.
Workstation Furniture

There should be sufficient space to allow the user of the workstation to arrange their equipment to their needs. It should be dimensioned and designed to allow sufficient space for the user to vary their body movements and find the most comfortable position in which to work.

The surface height should allow the user's arms to be horizontal (90 at the elbow). This can be achieved by the adjustment of the user's seating. However in exceptional cases (user very tall or short) it may require the desk height to be adjusted as well. Best practice shows that the depth of the workstation should allow the screen to be at least 45 cm away from the eyes of the user.
Ancillary Equipment

A document holder should be provided if appropriate. Use of the telephone varies from user to user therefore each user's individual needs will need to be considered. It should be placed in an appropriate position dependent on its usage. If it is used frequently consideration should be given to obtaining alternative means of holding the handset e.g. hands-free sets or speakerphones etc. Wrist rests (gel filled pads) can be required by the user to aid comfort or help conditions such as carpel tunnel.
Stress and Fatigue

Management of the risks of DSE use requires more than just a safe and comfortable workstation - it also requires good job design to avoid the consequences of stress and fatigue. Good job design ensures individuals have the opportunity to change posture, change activity and work at a sustainable pace.

DSE users must have the opportunity to break up spells of DSE use with other activities and breaks away from the workstation. It is the Managers' responsibility to provide the opportunity for breaks and the individuals' responsibility to ensure they take the opportunities provided.
Off- Site Working

If a DSE user is working at a location away from their main base, the DSE Regulations and this policy still apply. DSE users working off site regularly and/or for significant periods of time, must show that they are managing the risks of DSE Working by completing a DSE Workstation Assessment.

Managers must ensure that a DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist is completed by off- site DSE users and that individuals are aware of best practice for safety and comfort at a workstation as for anyone else on their team.
Use of Laptops
If a DSE user is working with a laptop, the DSE Regulations and this policy still apply. Laptops must have a docking station, separate keyboard and separate mouse when used at a workstation.
Lap Top Computers

A portable item such as a laptop/ tablet must be positioned and used, so far as possible, in the same way as full size equipment (see example plates below). The use of a Docking Station is encouraged to allow the use of a full size keyboard, mouse and monitor.
The need for a risk assessment still applies. Users can seek additional training and advice either from the Trust Moving and Handling team, Occupational Health or Health and Safety Team.
Use of Hand Held Computer Devices
Hand held computer devices may be in use within the Trust.

If the hand held computer device is to be used for long periods of time and/or for work requiring input of information, (content creation) then the hand held computer device must be provided with a separate keyboard and a means of standing the device and adjusting the screen height (the principles of best practice for working at any computer apply).
If the hand held computer device is to be used primarily as a source of information, (content consumption) then the following best practice guidelines should still be followed:-
Whenever possible place the tablet on a surface rather than holding it.
Use a light touch on the screen.
Enlarge the image/text to avoid leaning forward to view information on the tablet.
Take short breaks if using the hand held device for any period of time.
Hot Desking
All workstations in use across the Trust must comply with Health & Safety (DSE) Regulations.
Shared desk spaces must enable individuals to make adjustments for their comfort and safety and will at a minimum provide:-
All DSE users must have completed a DSE Workstation Self-Assessment Checklist and should apply their learning from that assessment to all other workstations they use.

Where a workstation is not used regularly by one person and is a common resource, a generic workstation assessment must be completed to show that appropriate adjustments are available at the workstation to meet the needs of different users.
The Workstation Environment Lighting

Any room lighting provided shall ensure satisfactory lighting conditions and an appropriate contrast between the screen and the background environment, taking into account the type of work and the vision requirements of the User.
Lighting should be appropriate for all the tasks performed at the workstation e.g. reading from the screen, keyboard work, reading printed matter, writing etc.
Individual lighting needs must be considered to help avoid eyestrain and fatigue.
Users  should  be  able  to  control  light  levels  e.g.  by  adjusting  window  blinds  or light switches.
Direct glare should be avoided. Consider the position of the workstation.

Where lighting is not sufficient - spot lighting (work lamps) should be provided. Where new /refurbished departments are being planned Sustainability Department should be contacted to provide sustainable / environmentally friendly innovative arrangements e.g. fibre optic day lighting units
Reflections and Glare
Measures to minimise reflections and glare must be taken such as, moving the workstation position, changing the lighting, provision of desk lamps, fitting blinds or window coverings.
Anti-Glare screens should only be used as a last resort Radiation
The levels of radiation emitted from Visual Display Units are well below the safe levels set out in international standards and therefore do not pose a problem.
Humidity

An adequate level of humidity shall be established and maintained. Electronic equipment can be a source of dry heat which can change the humidity levels of the office environment resulting in unpleasant symptoms such as dry throat, dry skin and sore eyes etc. Opening a window usually alleviates the problem. Advice can be sought from Occupational Health.
Space requirements

Prolonged sitting in a static position can be harmful. It is most important that support surfaces for display screen and other equipment and materials used at the workstation allow adequate clearance for postural changes. This means adequate clearances for thighs, knees, lower legs and feet under the work surface and between furniture components. There must be sufficient space for the worker to sit down and get up without difficulty. The height of the work surface must allow a comfortable position for the arms and wrists, if a keyboard, mouse or other input device is used.
Occupancy
The Approved code of practice L26 to the Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations state:

‘In most workplaces 11 cubic metres (11 m3) of space per person should be taken as a minimum. This calculation should not take into account ceiling heights in excess of 3 m. A space of  m3 per person may be insufficient if much of the space is taken up with furnishing or equipment'.
Software Assessment

All software purchase requests must go through the IT (Information Technology) department for approval. As part of the questionnaire sent to the software manufacturers several health and safety related questions must be answered. Where concern is expressed by either IT or Health and Safety/Moving and Handling Advisor the purchaser may be required to review the purchase.

Software packages purchased should be ergonomically designed to ensure they are user friendly. Where  there  are  choices  of  software  available  then  all  packages  should  be reviewed by the persons who are going to use them to see which is preferred and whether any issues are identified.
Other
Equipment associated with the workstation should not produce excess heat that could cause discomfort to the user.
Equipment associated with the workstation should not emit excessive noise that may distract attention or interfere with the normal conversation.
General workplace heating should be comfortable not too hot nor cold and humidity levels adequate to maintain a comfortable working environment.

Utilisation of a laptop for any extended amount of time may result in a user experiencing stiffness or pain in the neck or back. This is primarily due to the low height of the laptop screen that forces a user to constantly look down to see the screen. Studies have suggested at a 15 degree bend, the weight of an individual's head that the neck has to support increases from around 5 kg to 12 kg. At a 30 degree bend, an angle not uncommon when we're gazing at our laptop screens, that weight jumps to  kg.

This  DSE  Workstation  Assessment  Checklist  can  be  used  as  an  aid  to  risk assessment and to help comply with the Schedule to the Health and Safety (Display Screen Equipment) Regulations.
Work through the DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist, marking either the ‘yes' or ‘no' column against each risk factor:
‘Yes' answers require no further action.

‘No answers will require investigation and/or remedial action by the workstation assessor. They should record their decisions in the ‘Action to take' column. Assessors should check later that actions have been taken and have resolved the problem.

Remember the DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist only covers the workstation and work environment. You also need to make sure that risks from other aspects of the work are avoided, for example by giving users health and safety training, and providing breaks or changes of activity. Advice on these is given within (Appendix 1 & 3).

table_items.text: Are the characters clear and readable?
The screen should be clean and cleaning materials should be made available. Check that text and background colours work well together.
Is the text size comfortable to read?
Software settings may need adjusting to change text size.
Is the image stable, ie free of flicker and jitter?
Try using different screen colours to reduce flicker, eg darker background and lighter text. If problems still exist, get the set up checked, eg by the equipment supplier.
Is the screen's specification suitable for its intended use?
For example, intensive graphic work or work requiring fine attention to small details may require large display screens.
Are the brightness and/or contrast adjustable?
Separate adjustment controls are not essential, provided the user can read the screen easily at all times.
Does the screen swivel and tilt?

Swivel and tilt need not be built in; you can add a swivel and tilt mechanism. However, you may need to replace the screen if: swivel/tilt is absent or unsatisfactory; work is intensive; and/or the user has problems getting the screen to a comfortable position.
Is the screen free from glare and reflections?

Use a mirror placed in front of the screen to check where reflections are coming from. You might need to move the screen or even the desk and/or shield the screen from the source of reflections. Screens that use dark characters on a light background are less prone to glare and reflections.
Are adjustable window coverings provided and in adequate condition?
Check that blinds work. Blinds with vertical slats can be more suitable than horizontal ones. If these measures do not work, consider anti-glare filters as a last resort and seek specialist help.
Is the keyboard separate from the screen?
This is a requirement, unless the task makes it impracticable (eg where there is a need to use a portable).
Tilt may not be built in.
Is it possible to find a comfortable keying position?
Try pushing the screen further back to create more room for the keyboard, hands and wrists. Users of thick, raised keyboards may need a wrist rest.
Does the user have a good keyboard technique?
Training can be used to prevent: hands bent up at the wrist; hitting the keys too hard; overstretching the fingers.
Are the characters on the keys easily readable?
Keyboards should be kept clean. If characters still can't be read, the keyboard may need modifying or
replacing. Use a keyboard with a matt finish to reduce glare and/or reflection.
Is the device suitable for the tasks it is used for?

If the user is having problems, try a different device. The mouse and trackball are general-purpose devices suitable for many tasks, and available in a variety of shapes and sizes. Alternative devices such as touch screens may be better for some tasks (but can be worse for others).
Is the device positioned close to the user?

Most devices are best placed as close as possible, eg right beside the keyboard. Training may be needed to: prevent arm overreaching; tell users not to leave their hand on the device when it is not being used; encourage a relaxed arm and straight wrist.
Is there support for the device user's wrist and forearm?
Support can be gained from, for example, the desk surface or arm of a chair. If not, a separate supporting
device may help. The user should be able to find a comfortable working position with the device.
Does the device work smoothly at a speed that suits the user?
Response speeds can be changed on most pc's via the control panel. See if cleaning is required (e.g. of mouse ball and rollers). Check that the work surface is suitable. A mouse mat may be needed.
Can the user easily adjust software settings for speed and accuracy of pointer?
Users may need training in how to adjust device settings.
Is the software suitable for the task?

Software should help the user carry out the task, minimise stress and be user friendly. Check users have had appropriate training in using the software. Software should respond quickly and clearly to user input, with adequate feedback, such as clear help messages
Is the work surface large enough for all the necessary equipment, papers etc.?
Create more room by moving printers, reference materials etc. elsewhere. If necessary, consider providing new
power and telecoms sockets, so equipment can be moved. There should be some scope for flexible rearrangement.
Can the user comfortably reach all the equipment and papers they need to use?
Rearrange equipment, papers etc. to bring frequently used things within easy reach. A document holder may be needed, positioned to minimise uncomfortable head and eye movements.
Are the surfaces free from glare and reflection?
Consider mats or blotters to reduce reflections and glare.
Is the chair suitable? Does the chair have a working: ■ seat back height and tilt adjustment? ■ seat height adjustment? ■ castors or glides?
The chair may need repairing or replacing if the user is uncomfortable, or cannot use the adjustment mechanisms.
The user should be able to carry out their work sitting comfortably. Consider training the user in how to adopt suitable postures while

working. The arms of chairs can stop the user getting close enough to use the equipment comfortably. Move any obstructions from under the desk. Adjust the back rest forwards and backwards as well as up and down so that it fits the hollow in your lower back. Sit upright with your arms hanging loosely by your sides. Bend your elbows at about a right angle (90 degrees) and adjust the armrest(s) height until they barely touch the undersides of the elbows.
Is the small of the back supported by the chair's backrest?
The user should have a straight back, supported by the chair, with relaxed shoulders.
Are forearms horizontal and eyes at roughly the same height as the top of the DSE?
Adjust the chair height to get the user's arms in the right position, and then adjust the DSE height, if necessary.
Are feet flat on the floor, without too much pressure from the seat on the backs of the legs?
If not, a footrest may be needed.
Does the chair have a working: Seat back height and tilt adjustment?
The chair may need repairing or replacing if the user is uncomfortable, or cannot use the adjustment mechanisms, or if they do not function.
Is there enough room to change position and vary movement?
Space is needed to move, and stretch. Check for obstructions and consider reorganising the office layout. Cables should be tidy, out of the way and not a trip or snag hazard.
Is the lighting suitable, e.g. not too bright or too dim to work comfortably?

Users should be able to control light levels, e.g. by adjusting window blinds or light switches. Consider shading or repositioning light sources or providing local lighting, e.g. desk lamps (but make sure lights don't cause glare by reflecting off walls or other surfaces).

Display Screen and other electronic equipment may dry the air. Circulate fresh air if possible. Dry eyes can occur when looking at display screens and television screens because the viewer's blink rate is reduced. Remember to blink to refresh the surface of the eyes. Use of humidifier should only be considered if deemed appropriate by Estates and Facilities Management.

Can heating be better controlled? More ventilation or air conditioning may be required if there is a lot of electronic equipment in the room. Or, can users be moved away from the heat source? Closing window blinds in summer will also help. In difficult cases seek advice from Estates and facilities management.
Consider moving sources of noise, e.g. printers away from the user. If not, consider screens around desk areas, or other soundproofing.

Ask if the DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist has covered all the problems they may have working with their DSE. Changes made as part of this assessment should be given time to take effect. If problems persist, contact Occupational Health or the Safety Team for further support and information. Ask if they have experienced any discomfort or other symptoms which they attribute to working with their DSE. Users should remember that DSE use outside the workplace will also contribute to physical stresses, and should set their home workstations up in a similar way. Ask if the user has been advised of their entitlement to eye and eyesight testing. The Trust will pay for eye testing for all employees who are identified as users. This payment is conditional on production of a receipt for testing from an Optician registered with the General Optical Council, submitted with an expenses form to the line manager. Retesting will usually be allowed every 2 years, except in exceptional circumstances Ask if the user takes regular breaks working away from DSE. Sedentary work, even with good posture should be avoided for prolonged periods. If work breaks (interchanging DSE with other tasks away from the workstation) are not feasible, the User should spend 5 minutes of every hour being active to promote circulation.

data.text: Appendix 3.1: Manager's DSE additional guidance
As a Manager what do I need to do to comply with the Display Screen Equipment (DSE) Regulations

As a Manager you have a number of duties set down by these regulations. This guidance supports the information given in the DSE policy and will ensure you can readily fulfil these duties and provide the appropriate arrangements for your staff.
The key requirements are to:
What equipment should be assessed?

DSE is usually, but not always, a personal computer at a desk, with a chair, mouse, and keyboard. At a hospital, other workstations may also be DSE and therefore risk assessments will be needed. Some examples include ultrasound scanners, lung function testing equipment and CCTV monitoring stations. If the equipment consists of a screen from which information can be read, a device to input information (a probe, keyboard, and joystick) and a chair, it is likely to be DSE. When there is any doubt, confirmation can be made with the Health and Safety Team.
How should a workstation analysis or risk assessment be carried out? There are four stages in the risk assessment process:
Stage 1: Initial consultation with the employee

As a first step the local manager should consult with the employee at the workstation in order to collect information on the main tasks completed at the workstation. It is important to provide the employee with an opportunity to comment during the course of the assessment.
Stage 2: Ask the employee to complete the assessment DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist (Appendix 2.1 - 2.4),
With this information, observe the employee working at the workstation and record whether the workstation meets the minimum requirements detailed in Appendix 2.1 – 2.4.
Stage : Speak to the employee about any issues which could not be resolved when going through the DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist Assessment, and close off those that have been resolved.

Prepare an action plan of how the outstanding issues raised from the Assessment DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist will be addressed, who will take the necessary action and when the actions will be completed. This may require input from Occupational Health, and if trained in DSE assessment – The Moving and Handling / Health and Safety Advisors. Please note Trained DSE Moving and Handling / Health and Safety Advisor support general DSE assessment, Occupational Health are the primary authority or will can suggest best options for supporting a clinical conditions that may be adversely affected by DSE equipment

A copy of the completed risk assessment should be given to the employee for his or her records and for further follow-up where required. It is the responsibility of the Manager to ensure that the actions are completed.
Stage 4: Review the implementation of the action plan

You will need to revisit the workstation risk assessment if there are still issues to be addressed. You should consult with the employee and observe whether the issues highlighted in the DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist Assessment have been addressed. When everything is satisfactory, you and the employee should sign the risk assessment document in confirmation.
How should a risk assessment be reviewed?

Periodically, the information should be revisited to ensure that the set up and use of the equipment continues to meet the requirements of the regulations. If necessary or desired a new DSE Workstation Assessment Checklist can be completed.
When any significant changes to set up, software or equipment happen, a new assessment should be made.
Display Screen Equipment (DSE) Regulation entitlements
Eyesight tests & Corrective vision support (Refer to Appendix 3, 4.1 & 4.2) Who pays for the eyesight tests?

An eyesight test must be made available and financial assistance towards this is provided by the Trust. The process and financial assistance for eye sight testing can be accessed the Occupational Health DSE Standard Operating procedure.

To reclaim costs the individual must present a copy of the optician's charges for the eyesight test to their manager who will in turn follow the DSE Standard operating procedure to arrange reimbursement or budgetary support.

Please note: Where an employee obtains an eyesight test independently or purchases corrective appliances without Trust line manager approval, the Trust shall not be responsible for the re-imbursement of costs incurred (even if the test and appliances were specifically related to DSE use).
Who can carry out an eyesight test?
Any qualified optician or optometrist should conduct the eye sight test. How frequently should eyesight tests be carried out?

Employees have the right to an eye and eyesight test at the start of their employment if the work involves habitual work with DSE as well as at regular intervals thereafter. In determining those intervals, factors such as the ages of the employees, the intensity of DSE work, and relevant health factors should be taken into account.
What does ‘frequent breaks' mean in the Display Screen Equipment (DSE) Regulation?

Breaking up long spells of DSE work helps to prevent fatigue, eyestrain, upper limb problems and back problems. The manager must plan the daily work routine of a DSE user to incorporate breaks; short frequent breaks are more helpful than longer infrequent ones. For every hour of continuous seated DSE work it is recommended to break for 5-10 minutes of mobility away from the workstation (rest breaks). It is also helpful to alternate tasks away from DSE such as filing, or photocopying – any work tasks which involve being away the desk (work breaks).
Are there any risks to pregnant workers?

Although there have historically been concerns raised regarding ill-health among new and expectant  mothers using DSE, the results of scientific studies show no link between miscarriage or birth defect and working with display screen equipment.

The layout of workstations may need to be routinely re-assessed over the pregnancy period for new and expectant mothers, to make working arrangements more comfortable. This should be conducted as part of the new and expectant mother risk assessment.
